Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Analyzing recent earthquakes in Japan using high resolution topographic data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Societies affected by earthquakes instill policies informed by studies of earthquake geology in order to preserve life and resources. The Western United States and Japan are two areas that have seen recent and severe earthquake activity. These two areas have unique tectonic settings and are actively researching ways to "characterize" earthquakes along fault zones in order to refine seismic hazard. This project will investigate recent seismic events in Japan, focusing on the Itoigawana Shizuoka Tectonic Line, Honshu Island, Japan. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Koji Okumura a noted expert on earthquake geology, at Hiroshima University in Japan.

The surface expression of an earthquake can be critical to understanding the characteristics of a rupture event and a fault zone. The cracking, raising, and subsidence of land associated with earthquakes are indicative of processes in the upper, brittle portion of a fault zone. In the last decade, the periodicity and resolution of remotely sensed images from satellite and aerial platforms that can be used to "quantify" the surface have been advanced and applied to studying surface deformation by earthquakes. The complex interplay between earthquakes, surface deformation and surface erosion is broadly known as tectonic geomorphology. The goal of the scientific investigation is to assess seismic risk of the Itoigawana Shizuoka Tectonic Line through the process of objectively mapping faults, quantitatively depicting surface deformation, and understanding fault mechanics and kinematics. The study will assess the fault zone landscape as a function of varying climate, slip rate, geodetic (changing location of GPS stations) rates, and temporal constrains. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project goal was to participate in a meaningful exchange in order to strengthen research partnerships between Arizona State University, Hiroshima University and the Geological Survey of Japan who all participate in the Southern California Earthquake Center's (SCEC) VISES (Virtual Institute for the Study of Earthquake Systems) program. These are all groups with extensive working knowledge of active tectonics and are using new data and tools to better understand the complicated processes surrounding earthquake producing faults. Within the last decade, tectonic geomorphology has been invigorated by light detection and ranging (lidar) topographic data. With lidar data, a tectonically active landscape can be observed quantitatively and without the hindrance of overlying vegetation, buildings, or infrastructure, to assess the extent and characteristics of a fault zone.  High-resolution topographic data (<1 m per pixel) for tectonically active areas presents a new opportunity to quantitatively define the surface to better understand the response of surface processes (ie. Rivers, landslides, valley shape) to earthquakes over time. Because of the high cost of data collection and uncertainty of exact earthquake locations, these methods have not been well tested until recently. The first high resolution (<1m) topographic datasets to span earthquake events were collected in Japan for the Iwate-Miyagi earthquake (2008), and Fukushima-Hamadori earthquake (2011). The working knowledge of Japanese researchers for local tectonics and technology as well as willingness to collaborate with US earthquake scientists has advanced our understanding of active fault zones. This exchange has strengthened collaborations for current and future scientists.

The fellow laid out and executed a rigorous schedule to meet many Japanese colleagues, students, and researchers in order to share knowledge and discuss recent data, methods, issues, and ongoing research in both countries. Major accomplishments included attending a professional meeting, giving two technical lectures, teaching two short-courses, attending a technical workshop, training four students and one faculty on a terrestrial laser scanner (TLS). Additionally, field investigations, totaling 1.5 weeks, were completed in the Nara Basin, along the Itoigawa-Shizuoka Tectonic line (ISTL), and in the Itozawa area where ruptures from the Iwate-Miyagi earthquake (2008), and Fukushima-Hamadori earthquake (2011) were reviewed.
